intro: Mesochloa, commonly known as the water fern, is a genus of aquatic plants belonging to the family Salviniales. These plants are characterized by their delicate, floating leaves that are typically divided into small, finger-like segments. Mesochloa species are often found in still or slow-moving freshwater environments, such as ponds and lakes. Their reproductive structures, including sporangia, are located on the underside of the leaves, facilitating spore dispersal. The genus plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various microorganisms and small aquatic life.
